awd_titl_txt: CAREER: Coupled Electron-Proton Dynamics at Photocatalytic Interfaces
awd_abstract_narration:
With this CAREER award, the Chemical Structure, Dynamics and Mechanisms (CSDM-A) Program of the Division of Chemistry is funding Professor Jahan Dawlaty of the University of Southern California and his post-doctoral, graduate and undergraduate student colleagues to conduct experimental studies aimed at understanding how the motions of protons and electrons are coupled in photocatalytic reactions at interfaces.   The coupling of proton and electron motion in these reactions is believed to help to make these reactions take place more readily.  Photocatalytic reactions are important in realms as diverse as biology (photosynthesis) and chemical engineering (production of solar fuels).  Post-doctoral, graduate and undergraduate students working on this project will receive training in state-of-the-art laser and optical science, spectroscopy, and the design of complex experiments, while working on important chemical problems with significant real-world impact.  The young researchers working on this project will receive excellent technical training in laser science and modern spectroscopic methods which will prepare them for the modern scientific workforce.  Under the educational aims of this CAREER award, Prof. Dawlaty will build simple physical models to illustrate important physical chemical principles.

Prof. Jahan Dawlaty and his research group will use ultrafast laser techniques to study the interfacial chemistry of proton-coupled electron transfer.  He will use spectroscopic techniques to measure the synchronous motion of electrons and protons during photocatalytic events.  In the experiments supported with this award Dawlaty's group will study: (1) amorphous manganese oxide surfaces; (2) hematite surfaces and (3) and silicon functionalized surfaces.  The reactions will be probed using a variety of surface-sensitive spectroscopic methods, including two-dimensional electronic-vibrational correlation spectroscopy. From the proposed work, a new understanding of surface redox reactions, where protons are free from the Born-Oppenheimer approximation is expected to emerge. In the longer term, the work is aimed at guiding the design of interfaces with light-controllable proton activity is a new concept that has potential to unravel the mechanistic details of multi-electron and multi-proton surface redox reactions.

por.por_cntn:
A larger goal of contemporary chemistry has been storing energy into chemical bonds and consuming the stored energy in a controllable and efficient way. Reducing carbon dioxide to higher energy products such methanol and burning methanol in direct alcohol fuel cells is an aspirational example. Nearly all such electrochemical reaction are complex multi-step processes that require transfer of several electrons and protons to various intermediates at an electrode-electrolyte interface. Therefore, understanding the complexities of coupled electron-proton transfer and the molecular details of the electrode-electrolyte interface is crucially important.  

To address some of the above fundamental challenges, this project focused on two main goals as described below.

1)- Understanding the Molecular-Scale Electrostatics of the Electrode-Electrolyte Interface Using Vibrational Stark Shift Spectroscopy:

The protonation state of a molecule at an interface is intimately related to the polarizing electric field near the surface. Therefore, it is necessary measure and model these fields correctly on the length scales of molecules. The usual macroscopic approach of measuring the electric field as a potential difference with a voltmeter is not applicable on the molecular scales. Therefore, we used vibrational Stark shift spectroscopy to measure the electric field near an interface. This approach is based on relating the frequency shift of the vibration of a molecule to the electric field that is experienced by the molecule. We used benzonitriles tethered on model surfaces as vibrational Stark probes of electric field.  One of our most important achievements was measuring solvation electric fields on the surface and extending Onsager’s model of bulk solvation to the interface. This combined experimental-theoretical work created the backbone of our other Stark shift studies. Next, we applied this approach to an electrochemical interface, and examined the limits of the standard Gouy-Chapman theory of electrochemical interface. Furthermore, the nitrile frequency shift served as a measure of surface Lewis-acid base interactions. We showed experimental results for this shift and showed preliminary evidence of Lewis frustrated bond.

Our next discovery was revealing a correlation between the organic chemistry concept of Hammett parameter (electron-withdrawing strength of a substituent) and the polarizing effect of an interfacial electric field on the molecules near an electrode. We established this fundamental link by comparing the vibrational frequency shift of benzonitriles that were induced by a field on tethered molecules to the frequency shift that was induced by substituents at the para position. Its fundamental and practical value is beginning to be recognized by those outside the traditional physical chemistry community and is being applied to reactions on surfaces.

2)- Understanding Light-Driven Proton Transfer in Photobasic Molecules:

Control over proton transfer by light has the potential to drive acid base reactions in a entirely new way. A class of molecules known as photoacids that become highly acidic upon light excitation have been known for decades. However, their counterparts, or photobasic molecules, were not as well-understood. One of our primary achievements was to systematically study photobasicity in a family of quinoline molecules. We established the thermodynamics of the process across a family of substituted quinolines and studied the factors influencing the ultrafast kinetics of proton transfer.

Next, we examined whether these molecules would be capable of deprotonating alcohols. Methanol and ethanol are feedstocks to many chemical processes, including those in alcohol fuel cells. Their reactivity often is related to the ability to deprotonate them. Using quinoline photobases we were able to show that it is possible to deprotonate low-pKa alcohols using light. For methanol (pKa=15.5) the deprotonation was successful nearly half of the time. We also studied the thermodynamic limits of solvation in this process. Finally, a thorough kinetic investigation revealed that stabilization of the generated alkoxide by a second alcohol is essential for the process. We also initiated a collaboration with a catalysis group to install the quinoline photobases in the ligand sphere of a catalyst with the goal of driving the deprotonation of the active site with light.
